# Good News For Associates As Goodwin Matches Salary Hike
## The train keeps rolling.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 21, 2022 at 5:36 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/good-news-for-associates-as-goodwin-matches-salary-hike/&text=Good%20News%20For%20Associates%20As%20Goodwin%20Matches%20Salary%20Hike)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/good-news-for-associates-as-goodwin-matches-salary-hike/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/good-news-for-associates-as-goodwin-matches-salary-hike/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The Milbank salary increase — which is more accurately “the latest Milbank salary increase” because Milbank’s always the vanguard on associate compensation — continues to ripple through the ranks of Biglaw.

Now it’s Goodwin, which just announced a full match of what’s becoming the new normal for Biglaw salaries. As a refresher, here’s what Goodwin associates are now looking at:

Class	New Salary
Class of 2021	$215K
Class of 2020	$225K
Class of 2019	$250K
Class of 2018	$285K
Class of 2017	$325K
Class of 2016	$350K
Class of 2015	$370K
Class of 2014+	$385K
January pay will reflect the old scale, but February will see a retroactive bump to this new scale.

Bonuses, [announced back in December](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/the-good-times-roll-at-this-firm/), will hit direct deposit on January 25.

Congratulations, folks!

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. Joe also serves as a [Managing Director at RPN Executive Search](https://www.rpnexecsearch.com/josephpatrice).

# The End May Be Near As Stroock Loses More Than Half Its Partners To Hogan Lovells
## The future does not seem bright for this firm.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 30, 2023 at 11:12 AMOctober 30, 2023 at 10:59 AM
23
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/the-end-may-be-near-as-stroock-loses-more-than-half-its-partners-to-hogan-lovells/&text=The%20End%20May%20Be%20Near%20As%20Stroock%20Loses%20More%20Than%20Half%20Its%20Partners%20To%20Hogan%20Lovells)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/the-end-may-be-near-as-stroock-loses-more-than-half-its-partners-to-hogan-lovells/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/the-end-may-be-near-as-stroock-loses-more-than-half-its-partners-to-hogan-lovells/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Late last week, Pillsbury Winthrop [ended](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/yet-another-firm-ends-merger-talks-with-stroock/) its non-exclusive merger talks with Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, yet another law firm that seemed uneasy when it came to the “financial and other risks involved” with a Stroock combination. At the time, Stroock seemed to indicate that it had “options” — but unfortunately, it looks like those options may now include a possible closure, all thanks to the Hogan Lovells.

Late on Friday, Hogan Lovells revealed that it would be hiring 30+ partners away from Stroock in a mass lateral move, including the firm’s real estate team as well as its co-managing partner, Jeff Keitelman. More than half of Stroock’s partners are now headed to Hogan Lovells, which paints a rather bleak picture for Stroock. As noted by CEO Miguel Zaldivar, it was nothing personal. “We are on a mission to grow in the U.S., and this is an outstanding opportunity to deliver on our strategy to invest in premium practices and expand our client relationships,” he offered in a statement. “This is about growth in New York with a premiere team.”

The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/10/27/over-30-stroock-partners-to-join-hogan-lovells-as-ny-firms-prospects-appear-bleak/) has insights on what may be Stroock’s dismal future:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
What comes next for Stroock after losing roughly half of its partnership in a single lateral departure is not known, but given its financial difficulties, lateral departures and inability to find a suitable combination, the prospects are bleak.

Stroock’s partnership currently numbers about 46 partners, according to its website on Friday. It’s unclear how many would be left after more than 30 partners leave for Hogan Lovells.

“It is sad when this happens to a firm,” Kent Zimmermann, a strategic consultant at Zeughauser Group who specializes in mergers, told Am Law. “But, there is an opportunity for other firms to benefit greatly from picking up high-quality teams. But I feel for the staff and others in a bad position.”

Stroock was founded almost 150 years ago. It would be a real shame if things were to end so disappointingly for the firm.

[Over 30 Stroock Partners to Join Hogan Lovells as NY Firm’s Prospects Appear Bleak](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/10/27/over-30-stroock-partners-to-join-hogan-lovells-as-ny-firms-prospects-appear-bleak/) [American Lawyer]

# Sorry Associates, But This Many Of You Are Not Going To Make Partner
## Hate to break it to you, but the Tooth Fairy is also fiction.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 10, 2020 at 5:17 PMSeptember 10, 2020 at 2:54 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/sorry-associates-but-this-many-of-you-are-not-going-to-make-partner/&text=Sorry%20Associates,%20But%20This%20Many%20Of%20You%20Are%20Not%20Going%20To%20Make%20Partner)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/sorry-associates-but-this-many-of-you-are-not-going-to-make-partner/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/sorry-associates-but-this-many-of-you-are-not-going-to-make-partner/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. Note: Welcome to our daily feature [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

Hint: Only 11.4 percent of respondents have a much more statistically realistic perspective and say they are not on track to make partner.

# Two Of Reed Smith's Finest Will Be Stuck On Human Directional Duty.
## This is what happens when you don't give people a heads-up.
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onApril 4, 2023 at 3:45 PMApril 4, 2023 at 2:10 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/two-of-reed-smiths-finest-will-be-stuck-on-human-directional-duty/&text=Two%20Of%20Reed%20Smith’s%20Finest%20Will%20Be%20Stuck%20On%20Human%20Directional%20Duty.)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/two-of-reed-smiths-finest-will-be-stuck-on-human-directional-duty/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/two-of-reed-smiths-finest-will-be-stuck-on-human-directional-duty/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Going to court is a whole ordeal. Depending on who you are, the way you prepare for it can differ. Some prepare their arguments and paperwork. Others decide that the black suit they were going to wear is too somber for a contract dispute and decide to opt for the more appropriate charcoal gray. But one thing is for certain — you’ve gotta show up. You’d think that a big-time firm like Reed Smith would know that and pass the word along to the relevant parties. Thankfully, this judge’s court order should set things right. From the ABA Journal:

A Delaware judge has ordered Reed Smith to station two lawyers at the courthouse Tuesday with “Please See Me” signs, after the law firm failed to provide notice of a hearing, causing it to be rescheduled.

Vice Chancellor J. Travis Laster said the lawyers should be available to answer questions for shareholders of the ODP Corp., formerly Office Depot Inc., who show up at the courthouse expecting to attend the now-rescheduled settlement hearing, [Law360](https://www.law360.com/legalethics/articles/1593008) reports… Laster said one lawyer should stand in the courthouse lobby and another by elevators on the 12th floor, where chancery courtrooms are located. The lobby sign should be printed in a large, readable font with the message: “Settlement Hearing for ODP Corporation: Please See Me.” The other sign should contain a similar message.

Some might see this as an embarrassing consequence of an internal communication gone awry, but this could be so much more. Imagine seeing this on the courthouse lobby:

# On The Job: A Labor And Employment Rankings Round-Up
## Which labor and employment firms are the most overrated and the most underrated?
By [Brian Dalton](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brian-dalton/)  
onJanuary 27, 2017 at 11:33 AMJanuary 27, 2017 at 6:46 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/on-the-job-a-labor-and-employment-rankings-round-up/&text=On%20The%20Job:%20A%20Labor%20And%20Employment%20Rankings%20Round-Up)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/on-the-job-a-labor-and-employment-rankings-round-up/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/on-the-job-a-labor-and-employment-rankings-round-up/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Recently, Above the Law launched [On The Job](https://abovethelaw.com/on-the-job/), our new site focused on labor and employment law. On the Job is anchored by three new columnists — [Richard B. Cohen](https://abovethelaw.com/author/richardcohen/), [Evan Gibbs](https://abovethelaw.com/author/evangibbs/), and [Beth Robinson](https://abovethelaw.com/author/bethrobinson/) — all of whom are experienced employment lawyers. In addition to their expert commentary on substantive developments in labor and employment law, On The Job will also offer research, rankings, and other [features](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/should-you-be-a-labor-employment-lawyer-what-kind-let-us-help-you/) focusing on the practice area. Today we are presenting a new feature: a [round-up ](https://abovethelaw.com/careers/insider-survey-labor-employment-attorney-rankings)of findings from (primarily) the [ATL Insider Survey](https://breakingmedia.az1.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_7U5tOUuQwTAfSxS), with a focus on labor and employment law.

The [Insider Survey](https://breakingmedia.az1.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_7U5tOUuQwTAfSxS) provides an outlet for law students and lawyers to share insight and opinions regarding their schools and employers. To date, more than 22,000 respondents have taken the Insider Survey, including hundreds of labor and employment attorneys. When we compare L&E associates with law firm associates generally, one trend leaps out: we find that L&E associates rate their satisfaction significantly lower than their peers for every category we measure. Perhaps it’s not surprising that employment specialists are the most critical of their own employers? In a more upbeat finding, we also see that L&E departments are outperforming law firms generally when it comes to gender diversity in their ranks.

The [On The Job rankings round-up](https://abovethelaw.com/careers/insider-survey-labor-employment-attorney-rankings/) reveals which firms are rated the highest by their own attorneys on a range of “quality of life” subjects, including satisfaction with compensation, hours, firm morale, professional development, and firm culture. Finally, it shows the peer firms and practice groups that L&E practitioners consider to be under- and overrated.

# Top 25 Biglaw Firm Shares The Wealth With All U.S. Associates, Ignores Counsel
## Plus some offices are getting raises.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 16, 2021 at 12:45 PMJune 4, 2021 at 9:38 AM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/ks-special-bonuses/&text=Top%2025%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Shares%20The%20Wealth%20With%20All%20U.S.%20Associates,%20Ignores%20Counsel)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/ks-special-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/ks-special-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
There’s good news — at least for some attorneys — at King & Spalding.

The firm, ranked 21st on the Am Law 100 with $1,338,607,000 in 2019 gross revenue, announced special bonuses for associates yesterday. As one would expect from a firm with over a billion dollars in gross revenue, they’ve matched the market standard for associates, set by Davis Polk.

And there’s more good news for associates in the memo, especially those in smaller market offices. The firm also announced that they are moving to a unified compensation and bonus structure for all U.S. associates, so those offices that were not previously on the $190,000 scale will see raises.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Special bonuses will be paid according to the following schedule:



To be eligible, associates must bill 1,950 hours annualized, with an opportunity for catch-up payments if they hit their hours later in the year. Full memo available[ on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/ks-special-bonuses/2/).

Noticeably absent from the memo is the fate of counsel bonuses. And according to tipsters at the firm, folks that fall in that category are PISSED. It’s understandably frustrating to be busting your butt during the pandemic and then ignored when it’s time for appreciation bonuses.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
This isn’t the first time that counsel have been [left out in the cold when it comes to bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/remember-your-firms-special-counsel-this-time-of-year/). And we know that in Biglaw, even the nod of “counsel will get individualized bonuses,” often leaves counsel taking home less money than the associates they supervise.

Of course, as other insiders at K&S note, counsel may yet still get paid. There’s some past precedent that counsel will get their payment with the year-end bonuses. But as long as the firm lets counsel twist in the wind, wondering whether their hours matter to the firm as much as more junior attorneys’, the kind of resentment that feeds the lateral market will build.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Lawyerly Lairs: Biglaw Name Partner Lists Longtime Home -- For $4 Million
## He's moving on up -- to a nearby $8 million apartment.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJanuary 24, 2019 at 10:43 AMFebruary 28, 2019 at 4:34 PM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/lawyerly-lairs-biglaw-name-partner-lists-longtime-home-for-4-million/&text=Lawyerly%20Lairs:%20Biglaw%20Name%20Partner%20Lists%20Longtime%20Home%20—%20For%20$4%20Million)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/lawyerly-lairs-biglaw-name-partner-lists-longtime-home-for-4-million/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/lawyerly-lairs-biglaw-name-partner-lists-longtime-home-for-4-million/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/850-Park-Avenue.png)
The elegant exterior of 850 Park Avenue — please ignore the annoying traffic barricades (via Google Street View).

Associates at Schulte Roth & Zabel who bill big hours [fare well](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-firm-wows-with-market-bonuses-and-up-to-40k-extra-for-high-billers/). Partners at the Am Law 100 firm, known for its expertise in hedge funds, [do even better](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/03/15/record-profits-revenue-for-schulte-roth-in-2017/).

And [William Zabel](https://www.srz.com/lawyers/william-d-zabel.html), founding and name partner at SRZ, presumably does the best of all. So it should come as no surprise that he and his wife live in a luxurious, multimillion-dollar Manhattan co-op — which they just put on the market, for a shade over [$4 million](https://www.bhsusa.com/manhattan/upper-east-side/850-park-avenue-8c/coop/19378593).

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Here’s the news, as reported by [The Real Deal](https://therealdeal.com/2019/01/21/madoff-settlement-lawyer-lists-longtime-ues-co-op/):

Bow-tied super lawyer William Zabel is looking to upsize.

The attorney who was behind the massive Bernie Madoff settlement is leaving the Park Avenue apartment where he has lived with his wife for 38 years. The 850 Park Avenue unit is listed for [$4.2 million](https://www.bhsusa.com/manhattan/upper-east-side/850-park-avenue-8c/coop/19378593).

If you’ll allow me to quibble, it would be more precise to describe Bill Zabel as the lawyer behind the [Jeffry Picower settlement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffry_Picower). There were many, many settlements of Madoff-related matters, which have kept Madoff trustee [Irving Picard](https://www.bakerlaw.com/IrvingHPicard) and his BakerHostetler colleagues busy for several years. Zabel’s client, Jeffry Picower, happened to be the biggest beneficiary from the Madoff scam — and the Picower estate settled the claims against it for a whopping $7.2 billion. (Picower himself died in 2009, apparently after experiencing a massive heart attack while swimming at his Palm Beach estate.)

That’s a bit depressing, isn’t it? Let’s move on to a happier subject: Bill Zabel’s remarkable legal career. The Princeton and Harvard Law School graduate has long been a leading light in the world of trusts and estates — but he’s most proud of his pro bono work, and justifiably so. From his [SRZ bio](https://www.srz.com/lawyers/william-d-zabel.html):

For more than 50 years, Bill has been an advocate for social justice in the United States and abroad. His civic and philanthropic activities have included, among many others, authoring the amicus brief on behalf of the ACLU in Loving v. Virginia, investigating the cases of those who disappeared in Chile during General Augusto Pinochet’s “Dirty War,” serving as chair of Human Rights First, chair of Immigrant Justice Corps, trustee or director of New York University, The New School, Mailman School of Public Health, The JPB Foundation (vice chairman), The Lymphoma Foundation, chair of the Princeton University Planned Giving Committee, Sakharov Archives, Lincoln Center Theater and The Academy of American Poets.

His involvement in the Loving case — which returned to prominence in the past few years, thanks to the Supreme Court’s 2015 ruling in Obergefell v. Hodges, followed a year later by the critically acclaimed [Loving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loving_(2016_film)) film — is a highlight. As Zabel told the [Financial Times](https://www.ft.com/content/85badca6-c8d8-11e4-b43b-00144feab7de):

[H]is proudest civil rights achievement was Loving v. Virginia. Years later, after a speech he made when accepting the Robert F Kennedy Prize for advancing racial and social justice, three women of mixed race approached him. “They said they wanted to thank me because they wouldn’t be alive today if their parents couldn’t have married,” he says. “That was priceless.”

Bill and Deborah Zabel’s apartment, though, does have a price: $4.2 million. It also comes with a sizable monthly maintenance bill — $5,653, bigger than most people’s mortgages — and because the building allows for no more than 30 percent financing, the buyer will have to put down almost $3 million, assuming it goes for list price (which isn’t guaranteed, given the [challenging market for high-end homes](https://www.wsj.com/articles/new-yorks-wealthiest-cut-losses-as-manhattan-real-estate-falters-1543508960)). In exchange for all that, the new owner will enjoy three bedrooms (one of them currently used as a library), two-and-a-half bathrooms, and a tony Park Avenue address.

Let’s take a look around, shall we?

# First Monday Musings By Dean Vik Amar: Evaluating Legal Education's Vital Signs At The End Of The Academic Year
## It's a tale of the (relatively) good, the (pretty) bad, and the (downright) ugly.
By [Vikram Amar](https://abovethelaw.com/author/vikramamar/)  
onMay 1, 2017 at 1:48 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/first-monday-musings-by-dean-vik-amar-evaluating-legal-educations-vital-signs-at-the-end-of-the-academic-year/&text=First%20Monday%20Musings%20By%20Dean%20Vik%20Amar:%20Evaluating%20Legal%20Education’s%20Vital%20Signs%20At%20The%20End%20Of%20The%20Academic%20Year)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/first-monday-musings-by-dean-vik-amar-evaluating-legal-educations-vital-signs-at-the-end-of-the-academic-year/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/first-monday-musings-by-dean-vik-amar-evaluating-legal-educations-vital-signs-at-the-end-of-the-academic-year/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A lot of assessments are taking place this time of year. Analyses of the First 100 Days of the Trump Administration are among the most prominent examples, but each law school also uses this season take stock of the academic year. So in my space today I’d like to offer a few big-picture thoughts on the state of legal education generally these days, highlighting the (relatively) good, the (pretty) bad, and the (downright) ugly.

First, the (relatively) good: the employment picture. America’s ABA-accredited law schools just finished the process of collecting, submitting, and posting their job-outcome data for the Class of 2016 (the one that graduated last summer), and while the ABA has not yet compiled and publicly presented aggregate statistics for easy comprehensive analysis, my own review of the few dozen or so schools that I keep close track of suggests that – at least for schools considered in the top quartile of the nation’s 200 or so law schools – the overall percentage of recent graduates who were employed in full-time, long-term, non-university-funded law jobs (that is, jobs that either require a license or for which a JD is preferred) moved up a few percentage points this year. (I know that the creators of [Above the Law’s law school rankings](https://abovethelaw.com/careers/2016-law-school-rankings/) – which are generally published in late May – have for plausible reasons decided to [exclude “JD preferred jobs”](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/06/atl-vs-law-dean-vs-common-sense/) and instead look at bar-license-required jobs only, but I lump both categories together for today’s purposes.) A big part of the reason for the progress at many schools this year may be that the size of graduating classes has shrunk, so that even if the number of new hires out there is staying roughly the same (or even shrinking a tad), the percentage of new graduates who are employed has increased. But there are also schools (and I know this because we are one of them) that saw the absolute number of graduates employed increase quite significantly in the Class of 2016 compared to the Class of 2015.

A related point is that Biglaw hiring seems to be holding its own; the percentage of recent graduates employed at firms with 100 or more lawyers seemed to go up this year at several law schools I looked at, even if only by small amounts. At Illinois, we saw the percentage of law grads from the Class of 2016 employed at firms of 100 or more lawyers move up significantly to about 34%, which is higher than it’s been in at least six years. And, again, while our numbers may not be representative of other types of schools that feed different markets, our experience is consistent with the finding that the National Association for Law Placement (NALP) made for the previous year (the Class of 2015) that the only sector in which the absolute number of new jobs increased from the previous year was very large law firms.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Once more, it’s important to note that the two trends I just observed are certainly not true for all law schools – and indeed many schools whose employment rates have been under the most severe stress in recent years probably experienced much more uneven progress or even further slippage in the Class of 2016 – but I feel pretty comfortable in saying that the employment landscape is generally somewhat more favorable than it was just two years ago.

Let’s move from the (relatively) good to the (pretty) bad: aggregate application volume. Even though the number of LSAT takers in the 2015-2016 cycle edged up (for the first time in several years), that increase hasn’t yet translated into an increase in the number of people applying to law school this year. In fact, as of April 21, 2017, the number of applicants to American law schools is off about half a percent from the April 2016 number (which itself was up just a bit from the previous year). Given the steep slide in application volume over the past half dozen years, perhaps flatness over the past two years is progress. But I must say I think today is an historically great time to apply to law school — if you are interested in law and competitive for the stronger institutions. It’s easier to get into a great law school than it has been in many decades – every school, even Yale, is taking some folks it wouldn’t have accepted five years ago — the financial aid packages are very attractive, and, given class size reduction and gradual improvement in some sectors of the marketplace, the number of aggregate jobs and recent grads are coming into good alignment (especially for graduates of the stronger schools). Given these factors, and the increased awareness among many young folks of the importance of the powers and limits of government, a number of analysts expect meaningful increases in application volume in the coming years. But for now, still pretty bad.

Now for the truly ugly: bar pass rates. As writers for this website have admirably reported, bar passage rates in many states and at many law schools have been abysmal over the past few years. There was a lot of press recently about the [likely closure of Whittier Law School](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/whittier-law-school-will-close-leaving-disaster-in-its-wake/) in California. While the prospect of a fully ABA-accredited law school closing its doors is quite extraordinary, consider that Whittier’s first-time bar pass success rate on the California bar exam, where most of its graduates sit for the bar, went from an already troublingly low 43 percent in July 2014 to 38 percent in July 2015, to an almost hard-to-believe rate of 22 percent in July 2016. While, as I have [written before](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/first-monday-musings-by-dean-vik-amar-tightening-bar-pass-standards-and-the-california-problem/), the California bar examiners may be setting their passing score threshold at too high a level, these shockingly low pass rates at Whittier go a long way to explaining the decision by university officials to wind the school down. Even with the prospect of better aggregate times for legal education ahead, all law schools must figure out how better to enable their graduating classes to pass the bar. The academic strength of the students coming in is of course a factor, but every school, even ones with pass rates three or four times higher than Whittier’s 2016 showing, must attend to this issue more now than ever before.

Vikram Amar is the Dean of the University of Illinois College of Law, where he also serves the Iwan Foundation Professor of Law. His primary fields of teaching and study are constitutional law, federal courts, and civil and criminal procedure. A fuller bio and CV can be found at [https://www.law.illinois.edu/faculty/profile/VikramAmar](https://www.law.illinois.edu/faculty/profile/VikramAmar), and he can be reached at [amar@illinois.edu](mailto:amar@illinois.edu?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# Vault Ranks The Best Law Firms For Diversity (2020)
## Did your law firm make the cut this time around?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 5, 2019 at 11:15 AMSeptember 29, 2020 at 10:55 AM
36
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/vault-ranks-the-best-law-firms-for-diversity-2020/&text=Vault%20Ranks%20The%20Best%20Law%20Firms%20For%20Diversity%20(2020))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/vault-ranks-the-best-law-firms-for-diversity-2020/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/vault-ranks-the-best-law-firms-for-diversity-2020/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Over the past few weeks, Vault has rolled out a variety of law firm rankings — from the firms that are the [most prestigious](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/vault-100-rankings-the-most-prestigious-law-firms-in-america-2020/) to the firms that offer the [best quality of life](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/vault-quality-of-life-rankings-the-best-law-firms-to-work-for-in-america-2020/) to the firms with the [top-ranked practice areas in their region](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/vault-rankings-top-law-firms-by-practice-area-and-region-2020/) to the firms with the [highest-rated summer associate programs](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/vault-ranks-the-best-summer-associate-programs-2020/) — and there’s yet another important one that we’ll dive into today.

Money can buy prestige and can certainly improve your quality of life, but the diversity of your colleagues is worth more than what any salary scale can possibly pay.

In a companion ranking to the Vault 100, associates were asked to rank their own law firms based on categories most relevant to how the firm does at creating, maintaining, and fostering a diverse workforce, including diversity relating to racial minorities, women, LGBTQ individuals, and individuals with disabilities. To create the overall Best 30 Firms for Diversity ranking, Vault averages the scores from all four ratings.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
There was a huge amount of movement in the Top 10 this year. Which firms made the cut? Without any further ado, here are the [Top 10 Best Law Firms for Diversity](https://www.vault.com/best-companies-to-work-for/law/best-law-firms-for-diversity) based on Vault’s Annual Associate Survey for 2020:

- [O’Melveny & Myers](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/omelveny-myers-llp) (+1)
- [Carlton Fields](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/carlton-fields) (+12)
- [Constangy Brooks Smith & Prophete](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/constangy-brooks-smith-prophete-llp) (-2)
- [Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/orrick-herrington-sutcliffe-llp) (+1)
- [Ropes & Gray](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/ropes-gray-llp) (+3)
- [White & Case](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/white-case-llp) (+1)
- [Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/cleary-gottlieb-steen-hamilton-llp) (+16)
- [Littler Mendelson](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/littler-mendelson-pc) (-2)
- [Schiff Hardin](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/schiff-hardin-llp) (+1)
- [Finnegan Henderson Farabow Garrett & Dunner](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/finnegan-henderson-farabow-garrett-dunner-llp) (+7)
It’s worth noting that O’Melveny swept almost the entirety of Vault’s 2020 diversity rankings, while Constangy Brooks remained on top for Best Law Firm for Diversity for Minorities. Here’s some [additional commentary](https://www.vault.com/blogs/vaults-law-blog-legal-careers-and-industry-news/vaults-2020-quality-of-life-diversity-and-summer-associate-program-rankings-are-here) on that:

The firm not only claimed the No. 1 spot for Overall Diversity—moving up from its spot at No. 2 in the 2019 rankings—but it also ranked No. 1 as the Best Law Firm for Diversity for Individuals with Disabilities, Diversity for LGBTQ Individuals, and Diversity for Women. As one O’Melveny associate indicated, “There are few firms who take diversity as seriously as OMM.” …

In addition to O’Melveny—which also ranked No. 3 for Diversity for Racial Minorities—three law firms ranked in the top 10 of all five of Vault’s diversity rankings: Carlton Fields; Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe LLP; and Ropes & Gray LLP.

# Kasowitz Benson Wants You To Know They Could Beat Up Your Firm
## Kasowitz Benson Torres is looking into a little rebranding.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMarch 8, 2018 at 5:03 PMMarch 8, 2018 at 3:31 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/kasowitz-benson-wants-you-to-know-they-could-beat-up-your-firm/&text=Kasowitz%20Benson%20Wants%20You%20To%20Know%20They%20Could%20Beat%20Up%20Your%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/kasowitz-benson-wants-you-to-know-they-could-beat-up-your-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/kasowitz-benson-wants-you-to-know-they-could-beat-up-your-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
After a year that saw the [loss of a named partner](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/kasowitz-benson-loses-name-partner-lots-of-money/), the mercurial [rise](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/marc-kasowitz-will-you-accept-this-rose/) and [fall](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/kasowitz-checking-out-of-russiagate/) of its most visible partner as a played on the national stage, and a [management overhaul](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/kasowitz-benson-gets-two-new-co-managing-partners-after-a-year-of-insanity/), you can’t blame Kasowitz Benson Torres for looking into a little rebranding. Marc Kasowitz’s turn at the top of Trump’s ever twirling wheel of Russiagate attorneys — Russian Roulette, if you will — prompted observers to wonder if he was [destroying the firm](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/when-people-start-writing-about-you-destroying-your-firm-things-arent-going-well/) that bears his name. That’s not an image you want to leave with the public.

A whole new look is in order after that kind of year, so let’s [head over to the website](http://www.kasowitz.com)!

First off, the firm has dropped its “Superior Legal Minds” motto for “Creative. Aggressive. Relentless” which sounds much more like the tagline on a poster for a bad action movie about a humble watercolorist with a dark past drawn out of self-imposed retirement to hunt down the drug cartel that murdered his best friend — Bob Ross stars in “Happy Little Trees.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  


Check out Dan Fetterman in that picture. Is he grimacing or smirking? Is Fetterman the Mona Lisa of our age? I’m haunted by that image.

Be sure to check out the video because it’s just a sea of artistic quick-cuts and camera jerks that’s so self-serious that Tommy Wiseau goes, “hey guys, I think people might laugh at you over this.”

I think that’s an epee rather than a foil, to be honest.



Aw s**t. They’re gonna Million Dollar Baby your firm!

Seriously, everyone wants a lawyer who “fights,” but Kasowitz is really going overboard with the implied violence. We’ve got swords on one page, fists on another, and the world’s least subtle Goodfellas homage on another.

But it could be worse, you could rebrand as [mid-range men’s shoe store like Shearman did](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/biglaw-firm-rebrands-and-the-new-logo-is-lets-just-say-unconventional/).

# Why You Respect You
## Here's an insight from in-house columnist Mark Herrmann that you should put to use when you're seeking a job.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onFebruary 22, 2016 at 10:59 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/why-you-respect-you/&text=Why%20You%20Respect%20You)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/why-you-respect-you/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/why-you-respect-you/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Five years ago (heaven help me), I explained in this space why [everyone wants to hire himself](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/02/inside-straight-i-want-to-hire-me/).

The guy who nearly flunked out of Yale Law School doesn’t think grades make any difference: “The whole question is where you went to law school. I don’t care how well you did in law school, as long as you went to a great one. When I’m interviewing candidates for jobs, I’m looking for people attending schools ranked in the top five.”

The guy who ripped the cover off the ball at Podunk State Law School views things differently: “I think the very top students at all law schools are basically equivalent. If you were the top student at a lower-ranked school, you probably would’ve been in the top few anywhere. Deeper in the class, maybe it makes a difference where you went to school, but the outstanding students are basically all really gifted. I’m looking for the top students in the class; I’m not an elitist about where they attended school.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
I’m not trying to be cynical here; I’m trying to be realistic. I’m trying to describe accurately things that I’ve witnessed over time.

The more I think about it, my thesis — that you respect, more than anything else, you — carries far beyond the hiring process. Ask a rainmaker at your firm what attribute matters most in a lawyer: “Any idiot can do decent legal work. We’ve got scores of service partners here who can handle our cases. But what keeps the lights on at this joint? Business! We should richly reward rainmakers, because, without them, there’s no law firm at all.”

Walk next door and ask the best technical lawyer at your firm (who’s not a rainmaker) to identify valuable attributes: “I don’t understand why clients aren’t smarter about hiring lawyers. Who do they think is doing the work, anyway? Clients think that the smooth-talking, glad-handing blowhard is the lawyer they want, but that guy couldn’t actually do the work on his best day. Without truly gifted technical lawyers handling the legal work, clients wouldn’t hire us (for repeat business, anyway). Our reputation would collapse, and we’d be out of business. We should richly reward the most technically competent lawyers, because, without them, we’re toast.”

Starting to sense a theme here?

From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
You respect you!

Think about the managing partner of the office at your law firm (or the head of your in-house legal division). Does the managing partner stroll the halls, chat with the associates and secretaries, and do no legal work? Ask that person the meaning of leadership. Dollars to donuts says this is what you’ll hear: “The job of a leader is to maintain the employees’ morale. The manager has to see and be seen, know everyone’s name, and make everyone feel like the workplace is their home. Can you imagine us having an office managing partner who sat in her office doing legal work instead of walking the halls? That would be a disaster! A manager’s duty is to think about our people; that’s what motivates our people to do their best work.”

Or is your managing partner the more studious type, still taking depositions and revising briefs in his early 60’s, and calling his wife to say that he’ll be home for dinner tonight “at the usual time — maybe 9 or 9:30.” Ask that managing partner the meaning of leadership, and you’ll hear an entirely different story: “There’s only one way to lead — by example. I work harder than everyone else in this office; I do top-notch work; I bring in my fair share of business. That’s what we’re striving for here, and that’s the example that the leaders must set. I don’t have time to stroll the halls chatting with people; my job is to lead, and I can lead only by showing our other lawyers what it means to be a successful partner at this firm.”

Do you see the same thing in junior lawyers? I have: I had a buddy in law school who had played varsity golf (at Stanford, which had quite a team at the time), but was in the bottom half of our law school class. He’d walk into interviews for jobs and explain: “People with good grades are a dime a dozen; ten percent of the students in this class are in the top ten percent. But I may be the only person in this class with a one handicap. I’d be happy to golf with you — or your clients, or potential clients — whenever you like.”

I don’t think the editor-in-chief of our law review was making the same pitch.

Who do you respect?

You!

Put that insight to use when you’re seeking a job, and guard against that bias when you’re evaluating others. There just might be a couple of talented folks in the world who aren’t your [spitting image](http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-12-22/features/ct-tribu-words-work-spit-20101222_1_splitting-image-linguistics-mirror-images). (Click through that link; it educated me, so I naturally assume that it will educate you, too.)

Mark Herrmann is Vice President and Deputy General Counsel – Litigation and Employment at [Aon](http://www.aon.com/), the world’s leading provider of risk management services, insurance and reinsurance brokerage, and human capital and management consulting. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) and [Inside Straight: Advice About Lawyering, In-House And Out, That Only The Internet Could Provide](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614385394/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1614385394&linkCode=as2&tag=dealbreaker-20) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# Some Law Firms Are Losing Billing Cash Cows Due To COVID-19
## Lawyers should prepare for the possibility that some billing opportunities may disappear as clients and courts learn lessons about efficiency while operating during the ongoing pandemic.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onJune 17, 2020 at 11:19 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/some-law-firms-are-losing-billing-cash-cows-due-to-covid-19/&text=Some%20Law%20Firms%20Are%20Losing%20Billing%20Cash%20Cows%20Due%20To%20COVID-19)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/some-law-firms-are-losing-billing-cash-cows-due-to-covid-19/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/some-law-firms-are-losing-billing-cash-cows-due-to-covid-19/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This website has already detailed how law firms are adapting to meet challenges posed by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Indeed, law firms have implemented work-from-home programs, communicated with clients and counsel through videoconferencing apps more often, and taken other steps to operate in these uncertain times. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has also eliminated many billing opportunities for numerous attorneys, and this has had an impact on the revenue of many law firms.

As mentioned previously in this column, [court appearances are usually a cash cow for law firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/unnecessary-court-appearances-are-a-cash-cow-for-law-firms/). Even though court conferences may only take 10 minutes or less to complete, attorneys often need to wait in court for hours before a matter is called for a conference. Attorneys are often able to bill all of the time they spend in court for a conference, even if lawyers are just waiting for conferences to be called. In addition, attorneys usually need to spend an hour or two traveling to and from a court conference. Although clients have different rules about how much travel time is billable, attorneys are typically allowed to bill their clients for at least a portion of the time they spent traveling to and from conferences.

However, at the beginning of the pandemic, many courts adjourned numerous conferences, likely because they did not wish to hold conferences in person and did not have the infrastructure to hold conferences remotely. As time passed, courts have mostly been holding conferences through telephone and videoconferencing apps. Although there were some complications with people getting used to the technology at first, conferences by remote means seem to be going much more smoothly now.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Nevertheless, conferences by remote means do not present the same billing opportunities for firms as traditional in-person court conferences. When courts conference matters through remote means, the parties are usually scheduled to conference a matter at an exact time. As a result, attorneys are unable to bill as much time waiting for a conference as they could when they were in court before a matter was conferenced. In addition, since remote conferences do not require any travel time, attorneys have been missing out on billing travel time like they were able to with traditional court conferences. Although attorneys used to be able to bill several hours for attending a court conference, they are likely able to bill only 15 to 30 minutes of their time for court conferences in the present environment.

The way depositions have been conducted since the start of the ongoing pandemic has also impacted another traditional cash cow of billing for law firms. Attorneys used to be able to bill at least a portion of their time traveling to and from depositions just as with court conferences. For some depositions, attorneys can bill a substantial amount in travel time. Indeed, while I was working at a law firm that handled a number of mass torts matters, I would sometimes spend many hours traveling to and from depositions hundreds of miles away. Sometimes, the travel time billed to a client would pale in comparison to the time actually spent at depositions.

However, most depositions are also being conducted by remote means now in order to promote social distancing. As a result, attorneys are able to call into a deposition from home and have not been billing their travel time as they were in the past. This must be having a substantial impact on firms that rely on such billing for a considerable amount of their revenue.

Some attorneys may believe that disruptions in their billing may be temporary and that as operations return to normal, traditional court conferences and depositions will resume. Of course, some matters are simply easier to conduct in person, and it is altogether possible that court conferences and depositions will begin to occur in person more frequently over the next several months as many states gradually reopen. However, it is possible that the COVID-19 pandemic may permanently change the way certain tasks are conducted so that traditional billing cash cows lost during the pandemic may be permanently disrupted.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
For instance, I have heard more than one court attorney relate that they see no reason to drag all of the parties to court for run-of-the-mill discovery conferences ever again. Conferencing routine and noncritical matters by remote means is simply more efficient, and it might not be worth it for all of the attorneys to appear in court for such matters. Furthermore, clients may require attorneys to continue conducting depositions by remote means. Clients may not wish to spend massive sums on travel time and travel costs for attorneys to attend depositions when they are now familiar with how depositions can be conducted remotely at a much cheaper cost.

In the end, many law firms have struggled with issues caused by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, and the current environment has restricted the ability of certain shops to bill hours. Some attorneys may believe that such issues will begin to disappear as conditions normalize as COVID-19 restrictions are eased. Nevertheless, lawyers should prepare for the possibility that some billing opportunities available to them months ago may disappear as clients and courts learn lessons about efficiency while operating during the ongoing pandemic.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. # 10 Reasons Why Contract Express Is Best For Your Law Firm
## When was the last time you looked beyond product features to choose which application works best for your firm?
By [Thomson Reuters](http://bit.ly/2oxlTsO)  
onMarch 5, 2018 at 3:33 PMMarch 5, 2018 at 11:44 AM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/10-reasons-why-contract-express-is-best-for-your-law-firm/&text=10%20Reasons%20Why%20Contract%20Express%20Is%20Best%20For%20Your%20Law%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/10-reasons-why-contract-express-is-best-for-your-law-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/10-reasons-why-contract-express-is-best-for-your-law-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When choosing enterprise software for your law firm, most buyers look at a product demo and take it for a spin. When was the last time you looked beyond product features to determine whether an application such as Contract Express is best for your law firm?

You might know that Contract Express delivers enterprise document automation for global law firms and corporations that need contract drafting, management, and updates for agreements as large as 500 pages or more and as small as 10 pages or less.

Let’s take a look at 10 reasons why your law firm should consider Contract Express beyond mere product features. And when you’re thoroughly convinced this could be the right option for you to learn more, then give Thomson Reuters a shout. We’ll be standing by for that product demo and a test drive.

10 Reasons Why Contract Express Is Best

- [13 Patents and Counting.](http://bit.ly/2F6m5JZ) This has to be our number-one selling feature for Contract Express: 13 patents and counting. This is mind-blowing when you stop and think about the time, effort, investment, and commitment by the software developers behind Contract Express. Not only did they secure one patent to protect the product’s credibility, they secured 13 with more in queue. Knowing there’s a team of developers and patent attorneys behind this product to protect it should bring you peace of mind that this team has its customers at the forefront of product innovation.
- Easier and Quicker Markup Creation. Fewer Programming Hours Needed. It used to be that when a lawyer wanted to draft a contract, he spent an exorbitant amount of time with IT to make it sing. Now, with the functionality of Contract Express and its dynamic engine, lawyers can more easily and quickly draft contracts using markup variables. This is the key feature of Contract Express as a powerful document automation tool. The lawyer’s markup can be sophisticated and complex to accommodate the needs of the customer.
- Practical Law Integration. For law firms with a subscription to Practical Law and Contract Express, users earn a head start in the drafting process. There are upwards of 300 ready-made contract templates in Practical Law U.K. alone that Contract Express subscribers can access. In addition, if you subscribe to Practical Law U.S. or Practical Law Australia, there is a breadth of templates available. Each is produced and maintained by Practical Law’s expert editorial team.
- Trust in Process. Trust in software also means having trust in process. With Contract Express, attorneys are in control with less fear of mistakes, less time needed for updates, more trust in the process, less testing needed, and dramatic cost savings against time spent. When you eliminate the numbers of people needed to handle a contract, that’s more peace of mind for the legal team to trust accuracy in the finished product.
- Use a Questionnaire to Launch a Contract. How many details are needed to draft your contract without errors? For those firms drafting 100+ pages of contracts on a consistent basis, details are cumbersome and critical to get right. That’s why this software uses a patented questionnaire methodology to ensure the contract is drafted properly the first time. You can create approval flows, sign your generated contract, and above all, report on all the processes users use in the end-to-end flow.
- Saving Minutes vs. Hours. No one thinks about time savings with software programs because we all take software for granted. When you use Contract Express, however, you’re saving hours and hours daily by using the automated document assembly, questionnaire, and resulting template that help draft and maintain contracts. Your team is freed up for other billable work.
- Cleaning the Archives. Manual management of old files and archives requires someone in the know about file contents and the client roster. In this newest update of Contract Express, legal teams can schedule deletion of inactive contracts themselves. You can now set client alerts as reminders of expiration dates. This enhances data management and security while eliminating confusion of storing outdated versions of documents.
- New Search Technology. Have you ever hunted and pecked through a contract seeking details or terms? Now, you can use search connectors and target specific terms and phrases to pinpoint the document.
- Solution for Alternative Fee Arrangement. Law firms are always under the gun to reduce fees, especially for active clients with higher demand for legal services. One way law firms can save clients’ billable time is via Contract Express. By giving clients access to a contract drafting portal with its automatic questionnaire and contract drafting template, lawyers are in stand-by mode to help clients on an as-needed basis. Clients can add specific details that get incorporated into the document, and a lawyer can review the end product for accuracy. This creates loyal and grateful clients who can develop their own contracts 24/7 on a self-service basis.
- Win New Business. When isn’t a lawyer seeking new business? The advantage Contract Express provides to lure in and retain new clients is a secret worth knowing. Firms are using this document automation software as a marketing showcase in addition to offering basic documents on websites at no charge.
Contract Express by Thomson Reuters is the premier document automation software preferred by enterprise law firms and global corporations. It is changing the face of document assembly among lawyers and becoming a must-have product for legal teams the world over. Want to know more? As said, we’re available for that demo and a spin. Reach us at [www.contractexpress.com](http://bit.ly/2oxlTsO).

# Working In-House And Want To Switch Companies? Good Luck!
## Even though you may be more marketable given your previous in-house experience, the application process can be a challenge.
By [Stephen R. Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/stephenwilliams/)  
onJune 28, 2018 at 11:13 AMJune 28, 2018 at 10:58 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/working-in-house-and-want-to-switch-companies-good-luck/&text=Working%20In-House%20And%20Want%20To%20Switch%20Companies?%20Good%20Luck!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/working-in-house-and-want-to-switch-companies-good-luck/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/working-in-house-and-want-to-switch-companies-good-luck/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The playbook for moving between in-house and Biglaw is well known and pretty straightforward.

Want to switch from in-house to Biglaw?

Easy, kiss your personal time goodbye and be prepared to be a slave to the almighty billable hour.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Want to move from Biglaw to in-house?

Hasta la vista big paycheck and regular bonuses, who needs those anyways when you can count on being home in time for dinner with the family.

But if you are working in-house and want to move to an in-house role in another company, well, the playbook is not as clear and the path is a little more obscure. Even though you may be more marketable given your previous in-house experience, the application process can be a challenge.

First, when asked to interview with a competing company, you will immediately be struck with a nagging fear the new company only wants to meet you to gather intel on your present employer. We are attorneys after all, and we are known to be competitive by nature. Would you really put it past a fellow member of the bar to want to meet you only for their own gain?

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Second, even if the company really wants you for your brains, the interview process is a minefield. Think about it. How many of the most common interview questions can you really answer without running afoul of attorney-client privilege?

Tell me about the toughest decision you have had to make in the last six-months?

Well, that might be hard if your toughest decision related to steering your company clear of a lawsuit based on some fancy legal footwork you conducted with your current employer.

Tell me about a time you disagreed with a decision and how you handled it?

I’m pretty sure I can’t tell you about the time our CEO overlooked my legal advice in favor of a riskier route that ran us afoul of regulators.

From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
What do you consider to be your greatest weakness?

At the moment, it’s those darn rules of professional conduct that prevent me from really telling you how great I am while regaling you with stories of how I saved my current employer of a most certain doom and gloom.

So what is a current, now seemingly trapped, in-house counsel supposed to do if they want to leave for greener in-house pastures?

First, a bit of worn advice: network. Despite our companies being in competition with each other, I keep in regularly contact with my in-house counterparts at other companies. I can tell you which of them I would hire tomorrow if given the chance.

In-house life can be a bit lonely, so proving you are someone tolerable can go further to getting you a job offer than detailing your latest heroics.

Second, if faced with direct interview questions you believe you cannot ethically answer, answer the question at a more global level. As a healthcare attorney, the things the keep me up at night are likely the same as my competitors. You can demonstrate your understanding of the current pressure points in our field without revealing confidential information.

Finally, don’t be afraid to apply for a job outside of your respective niche. I may be a healthcare attorney, but I have negotiated enough employment and vendor contracts in my time that I am sure I could meaningful contribute to most in-house offices regardless of the company.

And when all else fails, complain about your non-legal colleagues.

Nothing will prove to me you understand what it takes to be an in-house counsel faster than your ability to relay the horror you are faced with every day as your respective company stumbles throughout the day as if the law did not exist.

Stephen R. Williams is in-house counsel with a multi-facility hospital network in the Midwest. His column focuses on a little talked about area of the in-house life, management. You can reach Stephen at [stephenwilliamsjd@gmail.com](mailto:stephenwilliamsjd@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# From Biglaw To Freelance Law: How Pivoting To Freelance Work Helped Me Find Balance As A Military Spouse And Mom
## Freelance work can be life-changing for you and your family, too.
By [MothersEsquire](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mothersesquire/)  
onMay 25, 2023 at 12:19 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/from-biglaw-to-freelance-law-how-pivoting-to-freelance-work-helped-me-find-balance-as-a-military-spouse-and-mom/&text=From%20Biglaw%20To%20Freelance%20Law:%20How%20Pivoting%20To%20Freelance%20Work%20Helped%20Me%20Find%20Balance%20As%20A%20Military%20Spouse%20And%20Mom)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/from-biglaw-to-freelance-law-how-pivoting-to-freelance-work-helped-me-find-balance-as-a-military-spouse-and-mom/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/from-biglaw-to-freelance-law-how-pivoting-to-freelance-work-helped-me-find-balance-as-a-military-spouse-and-mom/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts on motherhood in the legal profession, in partnership with our friends at [MothersEsquire](https://www.mothersesquire.com/). Welcome Michelle Camp to our pages. Click [here](https://www.mothersesquire.com/donate) if you’d like to donate to MothersEsquire.

In fall 2012, I made a decision that would forever alter my career trajectory: I married an active duty servicemember. At the time, I was a young associate in a large, prestigious law firm with no idea what the future would hold. My husband was very supportive of my career, and even passed on certain of his own opportunities to ensure we could stay in California so I could continue working for my firm. This is not always possible for military families, but we were lucky because we lived in San Diego where plenty of jobs were available to enable us to stay.

Fast forward to 2016, and I was a seventh-year associate at the same law firm, but now with two very young children at home. As if the demands of billable hours and two young children weren’t enough, that year became even more challenging when my husband left on a seven-month overseas deployment when our girls were just 18 months and 5 months old. As is common with military life, I didn’t have any family members close by to help pitch in from time to time, which left me solo parenting every single night and weekend. Most days, I would come home from work, relieve our nanny, put the girls to bed, and then get back online and work until the wee hours of the morning.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Somewhere along the line, I realized that working full time at a traditional law firm just wasn’t compatible with my life as a military spouse and mom holding down the fort alone so far away from family. At the same time, I wasn’t ready to completely give up my career, so I started looking into the possibility of part-time freelance work. Then in May 2016, I turned in my notice at the law firm that had been my “home” for my entire career, and took a big leap into the unknown.

I had no idea back then how life-changing freelance work would be for me and my family. It has afforded me complete control over my schedule, which has been invaluable with a deployable spouse and young children. It afforded me great flexibility and peace of mind when, less than a year later, I became pregnant with very high-risk twins, requiring endless doctor appointments and several hospital stays. And also when, a few years after that, the COVID-19 pandemic hit, causing immense uncertainty and closing offices, daycares, and schools. Flexible, freelance work has been a lifesaver during these difficult and unprecedented times and in general as a mom of four young, very energetic girls.

No longer tied to California for my job since I freelance from anywhere, my husband was able to take on opportunities that required moves, leading us to Alabama for a year for a master’s program, then to Nebraska, then on to Virginia where we currently live. It has been amazing to be able to move with the military without the concern of what I will do for work that many military spouses face.

In addition to providing complete control over my schedule and location, freelance work has also afforded me complete control over the types of projects I take on, and the people I choose to work with. These additional factors have made my legal career immeasurably more fulfilling, as I work on projects and with people I truly enjoy.

Because of freelancing, I can balance a career I love with the demands of motherhood and military life. Looking back, it was the best career decision I could have made.

Michelle Camp is a freelance attorney licensed to practice in California and Nebraska.  Since 2016, Michelle has been assisting solo practitioners, boutique firms, and in-house counsel with a variety of business litigation and labor & employment projects on a freelance basis.  She currently lives with her husband and four children in Chesapeake, Virginia.  You can email her at [mcamp@kaycamp.com](mailto:mcamp@kaycamp.com), or connect with her on Twitter @freelancelawmom.

# Morning Docket: 08.02.17
## * "We have a very crappy judicial system." Judge Richard Posner of the Seventh Circuit says the Supreme Court has far too few justices, and is calling for 10 more to be added to the high court's ranks, as he thinks the current arrangement on the bench is "[m]ediocre and highly politicized." Tell 'em how you really feel, Your Honor. [[Chicago Tribune](http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chicagoinc/ct-posner-supreme-court-0801-chicago-inc-20170731-story.html)] * "This is deeply disturbing." The Justice Department's civil rights division is planning to sue colleges and universities that engage in "intentional race-based discrimination" in their affirmative action policies -- that is, discrimination against white applicants. Hmm, wasn't this recently before SCOTUS... twice? [[New York Times](https://nytimes.com/2017/08/01/us/politics/trump-affirmative-action-universities.html)] * RIP, billables: Microsoft wants to completely eliminate the billable hour by entering into alternative fee arrangements with all of the firms it works with in the future. Twelve Biglaw firms and one intellectual property firm will spearhead this movement as the company's strategic partners. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/microsoft-announces-plans-to-nearly-phase-out-billable-hour/)] * The Department of Education has filed a motion for summary judgment in a suit brought by the ABA over public service loan forgiveness, claiming that its forgiveness eligibility determinations won't be final until 10 years have passed and that any eligibility letters sent thus far are nonbinding and merely advisory. How comforting for law grads drowning in debt? [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/08/01/abas-suit-over-loan-forgiveness-is-bogus-says-dept-of-ed/); [ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/education_department_seeks_to_toss_aba_suit_says_loan_forgiveness_calls_are)] * The Senate has confirmed King & Spalding partner Christopher Wray as the new director of the FBI. During his hearings, Wray said he'd resign if he were ever asked to do something immoral or illegal, as his "commitment is to the rule of law, to the Constitution, to follow the facts wherever they may lead." [[CNN](http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/01/politics/christopher-wray-fbi-director/index.html)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 2, 2017 at 8:42 AMAugust 1, 2017 at 10:48 PM
11
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/morning-docket-08-02-17/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2008.02.17)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/morning-docket-08-02-17/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/morning-docket-08-02-17/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

* “We have a very crappy judicial system.” Judge Richard Posner of the Seventh Circuit says the Supreme Court has far too few justices, and is calling for 10 more to be added to the high court’s ranks, as he thinks the current arrangement on the bench is “[m]ediocre and highly politicized.” Tell ’em how you really feel, Your Honor. [[Chicago Tribune](http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chicagoinc/ct-posner-supreme-court-0801-chicago-inc-20170731-story.html)]

* “This is deeply disturbing.” The Justice Department’s civil rights division is planning to sue colleges and universities that engage in “intentional race-based discrimination” in their affirmative action policies — that is, discrimination against white applicants. Hmm, wasn’t this recently before SCOTUS… twice? [[New York Times](https://nytimes.com/2017/08/01/us/politics/trump-affirmative-action-universities.html)]

[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/biglaw/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/in-house-counsel/)
# 'Biglaw Idol' -- Or, How In-House Lawyers Actually Select Outside Counsel
## Picking a law firm for a seven-figure engagement can take under five minutes.
By [Stephen R. Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/stephenwilliams/)  
onMay 18, 2017 at 2:04 PMMay 18, 2017 at 2:14 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/biglaw-idol-or-how-in-house-lawyers-actually-select-outside-counsel/&text=‘Biglaw%20Idol’%20—%20Or,%20How%20In-House%20Lawyers%20Actually%20Select%20Outside%20Counsel)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/biglaw-idol-or-how-in-house-lawyers-actually-select-outside-counsel/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/biglaw-idol-or-how-in-house-lawyers-actually-select-outside-counsel/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Over the course of the past month, our office has been debating which Biglaw firm to retain for a rather sizable engagement.

As a high-level overview of the facts, our hospital system is currently engaged in a dispute with one of our largest insurance companies. Under our interpretation of the contract, we should be reimbursed at a negotiated discounted rate of our fixed price for a particular service. Under their interpretation of the contract, they will reimburse us at a percentage of what Medicare pays for the same service.

If you are scratching your head at the above, you are not alone. It is rather wonky and an excellent illustration of why healthcare can be complicated. For the purposes of this article, however, you just need to know we had a material dispute in our contractual terms that we believe led to our being underpaid by more than $50 million over the course of the past few years.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
In my role, I have often been asked how in-house selects outside counsel for such engagements. While many think we have some formal decision making process in place, in my organization, the decision ultimately comes down to a few in-house colleagues quickly discussing before deciding whom to select.

Not convinced? The below is a near-verbatim transcript of a recent huddle where we decided who we would retain for the case in question.

General Counsel (GC): Well, given the size of this, I think there are only five firms in town I would turn to. Since this involves contract terms on a healthcare matter, I would eliminate Biglaw 1 and Biglaw 2 out of the gate since their healthcare practice is virtually non-existent. What do you think?

Counsel 1: Very much agreed, ma’am. Only Biglaws 3-5 could really handle this matter.
